articles.headline: Militants Pose Threat on Eve of National Elections in Iraq
articles.snippet: Iraq’s first nationwide election since the withdrawal of U.S. forces is set for Wednesday, and it is clear it will be held amid growing violence.
articles.abstract: Iraq’s first nationwide election since the withdrawal of U.S. forces is set for Wednesday, and it is clear it will be held amid growing violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Snipers line the rooftops across Falluja, waiting for a chance to shoot at government soldiers, should they try to invade. Homes have been wired to explode, too, just in case the government rushes the city. And roads have been studded with countless steel-plated bombs, of the type that killed so many American soldiers here.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Duraid Adnan

articles.headline: Yahoo to Offer TV-Style Comedy Series on the Web
articles.snippet: The move plunges Yahoo directly into the world of original programming, joining the likes of Amazon, Netflix and others to challenge traditional TV producers for viewers’ attention.
articles.abstract: The move plunges Yahoo directly into the world of original programming, joining the likes of Amazon, Netflix and others to challenge traditional TV producers for viewers’ attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, is about to dive into the shark tank of television-style original video.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Bill Carter

articles.headline: White House to Press Colleges to Do More to Combat Rape
articles.snippet: Reacting to a series of highly publicized rapes, the White House is increasing the pressure on universities to more aggressively combat sexual assaults on campus.
articles.abstract: Reacting to a series of highly publicized rapes, the White House is increasing the pressure on universities to more aggressively combat sexual assaults on campus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Reacting to a series of highly publicized rapes on college campuses, the White House on Monday released guidelines that increase the pressure on universities to more aggressively combat sexual assaults on campus.

articles.headline: Welcome to the Haiyatt. In China, It’s Not the Hotel It Sounds Like.
articles.snippet: Like many Chinese businesses with names and products closely resembling well-known international brands, hotels have come to see the value in borrowing the prestige of Western names.
articles.abstract: Like many Chinese businesses with names and products closely resembling well-known international brands, hotels have come to see the value in borrowing the prestige of Western names.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the Peninsula Hotel in Yangcheng part of the five-star Peninsula Hotels group known for its Rolls-Royces? Can you accrue Marriott rewards points at the Marvelot Hotel, which includes the Chinese characters for Marriott in its name? Is the Haiyatt hotel in China a Hyatt brand hotel? No, no and no.

articles.headline: At Meeting, Fed Likely to Again Cut Bond Buying
articles.snippet: The Fed’s policy wing is expected to cut another $10 billion from its monthly bond purchases, to $45 billion, ending the purchases this fall.
articles.abstract: The Fed’s policy wing is expected to cut another $10 billion from its monthly bond purchases, to $45 billion, ending the purchases this fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is tiptoeing away from its economic stimulus campaign, and so far the broader economy has barely noticed.

articles.headline: G.A.O. Report Sees Deeper Bank Flaws in Foreclosures
articles.snippet: When regulators decided to end the independent foreclosure review last year, most banks had not completed the examinations of their foreclosure practices.
articles.abstract: When regulators decided to end the independent foreclosure review last year, most banks had not completed the examinations of their foreclosure practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new government report suggests that errors made by banks and their agents during foreclosures might have been significantly higher than was previously believed when regulators halted a national review of the banks’ mortgage servicing operations.

articles.headline: Pfizer Proposes a Marriage With AstraZeneca, Easing Taxes in a Move to Britain
articles.snippet: Pfizer proposed a $99 billion acquisition of its British rival AstraZeneca that would allow it to reincorporate in Britain.
articles.abstract: Pfizer proposed a $99 billion acquisition of its British rival AstraZeneca that would allow it to reincorporate in Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pfizer, the maker of best-selling drugs like Lipitor and Viagra and a symbol of business prowess in the United States for more than a century, no longer wants to be an American company.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Sanctions Over Ukraine Cause Headaches in the Energy Sector
articles.snippet: With the latest round of sanctions over the Ukraine crisis, relationships between Russian state-owned businesses and large multinational companies look increasingly complicated.
articles.abstract: With the latest round of sanctions over the Ukraine crisis, relationships between Russian state-owned businesses and large multinational companies look increasingly complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Once a year, the chief executives of the world’s largest oil companies fly to St. Petersburg, Russia’s second city, for an economic forum and a rare chance to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin and his lieutenant in the energy business, Igor I. Sechin.

articles.headline: A Deadly Fungus and Questions at a Hospital
articles.snippet: A medical journal that cited the handling of linens in the outbreak of a flesh-eating fungus at a New Orleans hospital has caused new pain for the families of five children who died.
articles.abstract: A medical journal that cited the handling of linens in the outbreak of a flesh-eating fungus at a New Orleans hospital has caused new pain for the families of five children who died.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The first victim was a premature boy in the intensive care unit whose mother noticed a mysterious irritation in his groin; it grew into an open wound burrowing into the baby’s abdomen. The last patient to die was a 10-year-old girl, whose face was ravaged.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: Ending Asia Trip, Obama Defends His Foreign Policy
articles.snippet: President Obama said his policies were based on a workmanlike attention to American priorities that might lack the high drama of a wartime presidency but also avoids ruinous mistakes.
articles.abstract: President Obama said his policies were based on a workmanlike attention to American priorities that might lack the high drama of a wartime presidency but also avoids ruinous mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Obama, stung by criticism of his response to turmoil from Eastern Europe to the Middle East, defended his approach to foreign policy as a slow but steady pursuit of American interests while avoiding military conflict, and he lashed out at those he said reflexively call for the use of force.

articles.headline: Settling the Bets of the Private-Equity Megadeal’s Golden Age
articles.snippet: Energy Future Holdings, formerly TXU Corporation, symbolized an era’s huge private equity buyouts.
articles.abstract: Energy Future Holdings, formerly TXU Corporation, symbolized an era’s huge private equity buyouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:49 p.m. | It has long been the $45 billion corporate buyout that should never have happened.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Top Officer of Barclays in America Is Leaving
articles.snippet: Hugh E. McGee III will leave his post on Wednesday, even as the bank prepares to create a new holding company for its American business by July 2016.
articles.abstract: Hugh E. McGee III will leave his post on Wednesday, even as the bank prepares to create a new holding company for its American business by July 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Barclays of Britain fought to become one of Wall Street’s elite investment banks, including by buying the remains of Lehman Brothers’ American operations.
articles.byline: By Chad Bray and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Justices Back Rule Limiting Coal Pollution
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court upheld the E.P.A.’s authority to regulate coal-plant pollution that drifts from more than two dozen Midwestern and Appalachian states to the East Coast.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court upheld the E.P.A.’s authority to regulate coal-plant pollution that drifts from more than two dozen Midwestern and Appalachian states to the East Coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major victory for the Obama administration, the Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld the authority of the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate the smog from coal plants that drifts across state lines from 28 Midwestern and Appalachian states to the East Coast.
